content.title: Market Structures and Consumer Choice
content.subtitle: Understand how market competition shapes prices, choices, and your power as a consumer in {{STATE_NAME}}

content.label: Essential Question
content.question:
If one company controls your local internet service, what happens when they raise prices by 40%?

Your options depend entirely on the market structure ‚Äî and understanding it gives you power as a consumer.

objectives.description: The four main market structures ‚Äî perfect competition, monopolistic competition, oligopoly, and monopoly ‚Äî and their defining characteristics
How market structure affects prices, output levels, and consumer welfare in real-world industries
How competition drives innovation, efficiency, and lower prices while market power can harm consumers
Market structure concepts to industries you interact with daily in {{STATE_NAME}} as an informed consumer

terms.definition: A market structure with many sellers offering identical products, where no single firm can influence price ‚Äî each firm is a price taker
terms.example: Agricultural commodities like wheat or corn, where hundreds of farmers sell the same product at the market price

terms.definition: A market structure where a single seller controls the entire supply of a product with no close substitutes, giving them significant pricing power
terms.example: A local utility company providing electricity ‚Äî you can't simply switch to a competitor if you dislike their rates

terms.definition: A market dominated by a small number of large firms whose decisions significantly affect each other ‚Äî leading to strategic behavior and limited competition
terms.example: The US airline industry, where a few major carriers control most routes and often match each other's pricing

terms.definition: Many sellers offering differentiated products that are similar but not identical, allowing some pricing power through brand or product differences
terms.example: Restaurants, clothing brands, or hair salons ‚Äî many options exist, but each offers a slightly different experience

leftColumn.title: More Competition
items: Perfect Competition ‚Äî Many sellers, identical goods, price takers (wheat, corn)
Monopolistic Competition ‚Äî Many sellers, differentiated goods, some pricing power (restaurants, clothing)
Low barriers to entry ‚Äî New firms can join easily
Prices stay close to cost of production
Consumers benefit most from variety and low prices

rightColumn.title: Less Competition
items: Oligopoly ‚Äî Few large firms, strategic behavior, coordinated pricing (airlines, cell carriers)
Monopoly ‚Äî One seller, no substitutes, full pricing power (some utilities)
High barriers to entry ‚Äî Hard for new firms to compete
Prices above cost of production ‚Äî firms earn higher profits
Consumers have fewer choices and pay more

content.headerTitle: Market Power and Barriers to Entry

leftPanel.title: What Keeps Competitors Out?
paragraphs: Barriers to entry are the obstacles that prevent new firms from competing in a market. Higher barriers mean less competition ‚Äî and more power for existing firms.
bulletPoints: Startup Costs ‚Äî Building a factory or power grid requires billions in capital
Patents & Licenses ‚Äî Legal protections that block competitors for years
Economies of Scale ‚Äî Large firms produce cheaper per unit than small firms can
Brand Loyalty ‚Äî Established brands like Apple or Nike are hard to displace
Network Effects ‚Äî Products become more valuable as more people use them (social media)

stats.label: US airlines control 80% of domestic air travel
Cost to enter a perfectly competitive market

layoutData.title: Competition Is Your Best Friend
paragraphs: When markets are competitive, businesses must earn your business ‚Äî they lower prices, improve quality, and innovate constantly. When competition disappears, consumers lose that protection.
bulletPoints: Lower Prices: Rivals force each firm to price near the actual cost of production ‚Äî excess profits attract competitors who undercut prices
Innovation: Companies invest in better products to win market share ‚Äî competition produced the smartphone revolution
Quality Improvement: Poor quality loses customers to competitors immediately in competitive markets
Consumer Surplus: The gap between what you'd pay and what you actually pay grows larger with more competition

keyPoint.text: üí° The smartphone market went from $600 iPhones (2007) to hundreds of quality competitors ‚Äî competition drove better phones at lower prices.

leftPanel.title: When One Firm Wins, Consumers Lose
paragraphs: A monopoly or near-monopoly can charge higher prices, provide lower quality, and invest less in innovation ‚Äî because customers have nowhere else to go.
bulletPoints: Higher Prices ‚Äî Without competition, monopolists charge what the market will bear
Deadweight Loss ‚Äî Transactions that would benefit both buyer and seller don't happen because price is too high
Reduced Innovation ‚Äî Less pressure to improve products or services
Regulatory Need ‚Äî Governments regulate utilities and use antitrust laws to prevent harmful monopolies in {{STATE_NAME}} and nationwide

stats.label: Typical price premium charged by monopolists over competitive price
Fine paid by Google for antitrust violations in Europe
Year US Sherman Antitrust Act passed to protect competition

content.headerTitle: Oligopoly ‚Äî When a Few Firms Dominate

leftPanel.title: Strategic Behavior in Oligopolies
paragraphs: In an oligopoly, a small number of firms control the market. Each firm's decisions directly affect the others ‚Äî so they watch competitors closely and act strategically.
bulletPoints: Price Leadership ‚Äî One firm sets price, others follow to avoid price wars
Collusion Risk ‚Äî Firms may illegally coordinate pricing (price-fixing), which is banned by antitrust law
Non-Price Competition ‚Äî Firms compete through advertising, loyalty programs, and product features instead of price cuts
Examples in {{STATE_NAME}}: Wireless carriers (Verizon, AT&T, T-Mobile), streaming services, major airlines serving your region

stats.label: Cell carriers control 98% of US wireless subscribers
Annual advertising spend by major wireless carriers competing for customers
Penalty for executives convicted of price-fixing collusion

layoutData.title: Many Sellers, Differentiated Products
paragraphs: Most consumer markets fall into monopolistic competition ‚Äî many businesses offering similar but distinct products. Your choice of restaurant, gym, or clothing brand illustrates this structure every day.
bulletPoints: Product Differentiation: Each seller offers a slightly different product ‚Äî taste, location, atmosphere, brand identity create distinctions
Some Pricing Power: A popular restaurant can charge more than nearby competitors if customers value their unique experience
Easy Entry and Exit: New restaurants open and close constantly ‚Äî poor performers exit when they lose customers
Advertising Matters: Firms spend heavily on marketing to differentiate and attract loyal customers

keyPoint.text: üí° In {{STATE_NAME}}, your choice between coffee shops, gyms, hair salons, and clothing retailers is shaped by monopolistic competition ‚Äî enough options to have choice, but each firm has some pricing power through differentiation.

leftPanel.title: Real Industries Around You
paragraphs: Every market you participate in as a consumer fits one of the four market structures. Recognizing which structure applies changes how you evaluate your options.
bulletPoints: Perfect Competition ‚Äî Local farmers markets, agricultural goods, some commodity markets
Monopolistic Competition ‚Äî Restaurants, gyms, clothing stores, hair salons, coffee shops in {{STATE_NAME}}
Oligopoly ‚Äî Internet service providers in your area, wireless carriers, major grocery chains
Monopoly/Near-Monopoly ‚Äî Local utility companies (electricity, water), some cable providers with exclusive territory agreements

stats.label: ISPs available in many rural {{STATE_NAME}} areas ‚Äî limited competition
Restaurants competing for your dining dollar in urban {{STATE_NAME}}
Utility monopolies in {{STATE_NAME}} face price regulation by state government

scenario.name: Sofia ‚Äî Choosing a Cell Phone Plan
paragraphs: Sofia needs a new wireless plan. She lives in a major city in {{STATE_NAME}} where three major carriers compete. She researches prices, data limits, and coverage maps for each option.

Because she understands oligopoly, Sofia knows the carriers watch each other's pricing ‚Äî when one carrier runs a promotion, others often match it within days. She times her purchase during a competitive promotion cycle and saves $30/month.

scenario.name: Marcus ‚Äî Stuck with One ISP
paragraphs: Marcus moved to a rural area of {{STATE_NAME}} where only one internet service provider operates. When the ISP raised monthly rates by 35% and reduced speeds, Marcus had no alternatives.
Without competition, Marcus had to pay the higher price or go without internet ‚Äî a real-world consequence of monopoly power and insufficient market competition.

content.question:
Think about a market you participate in regularly ‚Äî your cell phone carrier, streaming services, local grocery stores, or internet provider. What market structure does it fit?

Does competition benefit you in this market? Do you feel like you have real choices, or are your options limited? How does market structure affect your experience as a consumer?

Should governments break up large companies or prevent mergers to protect competition? Or should markets be left alone to determine outcomes?

Think about industries like tech (Google, Amazon, Apple), airlines, or healthcare in {{STATE_NAME}}. What are the trade-offs between allowing large firms to benefit from scale versus protecting consumer choice and competitive prices?

questions.question: What is the key difference between a monopoly and an oligopoly? Give a real-world example of each.
Why do barriers to entry matter for market structure? Name two types of barriers and explain how each limits competition.
How does monopolistic competition differ from perfect competition? Why might a firm in monopolistic competition be able to charge higher prices?
As a consumer in {{STATE_NAME}}, how can understanding market structure help you make better purchasing decisions?

takeaways.title: Four Structures, Different Outcomes
takeaways.description: Perfect competition, monopolistic competition, oligopoly, and monopoly each produce different prices, quality, and consumer choices

takeaways.title: Competition Protects Consumers
takeaways.description: More competition means lower prices, higher quality, and more innovation ‚Äî monopolies can charge more and improve less

takeaways.title: Barriers Determine Power
takeaways.description: High barriers to entry protect existing firms and reduce competition ‚Äî patents, startup costs, and network effects create market power

takeaways.title: Know Your Market
takeaways.description: Identifying the market structure you're buying in ‚Äî oligopoly, monopoly, or competitive ‚Äî helps you understand your leverage as a consumer in {{STATE_NAME}}

main.title: Market Structure Analyzer
main.description: Analyze real markets to identify their structure and evaluate how that structure affects prices, competition, and your choices as a consumer. Use market data from industries you interact with in {{STATE_NAME}}.

steps: Select a Market ‚Äî Choose an industry (wireless carriers, streaming services, local grocery stores, internet providers)
Identify the Structure ‚Äî Count the number of sellers, assess product differentiation, and evaluate barriers to entry
Analyze the Outcomes ‚Äî What prices do consumers pay? How much choice exists? What drives competition or limits it?
Compare Structures ‚Äî Contrast your chosen market with a more competitive and less competitive alternative
Make a Consumer Decision ‚Äî Based on your analysis, what strategy should a consumer use when buying in this market?

content.tagline: Know the Market, Know Your Power
